item.title: Don't Waste Your Time Learning Everything
item.description: Motivated by this post that was itself inspired by this LinkedIn post. This LinkedIn post say Stick to Python and C++, Swift for TensorFlow was nice but it’s pretty much dead, and all other languages who are too pretty, academic, lonely and dying

item.title: Speed Up Your Site with a CDN: Content Delivery Network Essentials
item.description: One scenario where I need a CDN is for dynamically requesting static JavaScript files on my website. Hosting these large JS files myself would significantly impact my bandwidth usage since my host charges based on traffic volume. Using a CDN helps solve this issue by distributing requests across its worldwide network of data centers. Not only does this improve access speeds by caching files closer to users, it also reduces my origin server load and bandwidth costs.

item.title: A Year in Moments: 2023 Video Blog
item.description: Throughout the year, I captured short video clips documenting my travels, adventures, and life events using my camera. For summaries of my 2023 photos, please check out:  jerrysmd.github.io/gallery And to read recaps of the books I enjoyed in 2023:  jerrysmd.notion.site

item.title: Striking a Balance Between Speed and Compression Ratio: The Relationship Between Compression Algorithms and Formats
item.description: Some common compression formats include zip, rar, and 7z. Common compression algorithms include gzip, brotli, zstd, lz4, pigz, isa-l, and pzstd. However, what are the relationships between these? How can one strike a balance between compression speed and ratio? What is the relationship between compression algorithms and formats?

item.title: Exploring JDK 21 New Feature: Virtual Threads
item.description: JDK 21, the latest LTS release of OpenJDK, introduces an exciting new feature called Virtual Threads. In this blog post, we will delve into the details of this feature and explore how it enhances the scalability and performance of concurrent applications.

item.title: Tracking SQLite Database Changes in Git
item.description: SQLite stores data in binary. If you run cat mydb.sqlite, you’ll see a bunch of gibberish that doesn’t resemble structured data at all. If you want to track changes and updates to a database using Git, you won’t be able to see full diffs by default.
